TO  THE  MEMBERS  0¥  THE  BAI^NATYNE  CLUB. 


When  I  first  undertook  to  print  the  llegister  of  Dryburgli  for  presentation  to 
tlio  Club,  I  had  never  seen  it,  and  was  not  at  all  aware  of  its  vcry  imperfoct 
and  defective  state. 

On  examining  the  proof-sheets,  I  perceived  that  it  not  only  wanted  f-ome 
of  the  earhest  Charters,  which  it  must  have  originally  contained,  and  among 
these  the  Foundation  Charter,  but  that  it  broke  oif  abruptly,  before  the  suppres- 
sion  of  thc  Monastery  ;  and  that,  in  the  grcater  number  of  the  Chartors  and  other 
dceds  which  the  Register  still  contains,  the  dates,  and  the  nanies  of  the  witnesses 
are  omitted,  wliich  considerably  diminishes  its  usefulness. 

It  disappointcd  me  to  think  that  my  contribution  to  the  Club  should  be  so 
iiicompletc  ;  and  I  determined,  though  it  might  cost  some  troublc  and  expense,  to 
eudcavour,  as  far  as  possible,  to  supply  the  defects  of  the  Register,  by  obtaining 
permission  to  inspect  the  repositories  of  the  several  pcrsons  who  now  possess  lands 
formerly  belonging  to  thc  Abbey,  in  order  to  recover  and  make  copies  of  sucli 
original  Charters  and  other  writings  relating  to  it  as  might  still  be  in  cxistcnce. 

In  doing  this  I  had  no  difficulty.  Bcing  unable  personally  to  makc  this 
inspection,  I  obtained  the  wilHng  assistance  of  MrWiUiam  Fraser  of  Edinburgli, 
a  gentleman  well  qualified  for  thc  task,  from  his  intimate  acquaintancc  with  ohl 
writings,  and  from  his  zcal  and  intelligenco  in  antiquarian  research.  Through 
him  inspection  Iias  been  madc  of  the  titlc-dccds,  &c.  of  Thc  Duke  of  Rich- 
mond,  Thc  Earls  of  Mar,  Buchan,  and  Laudcrdalc,  Lord  Pohrarth,  8ir  Wyndham 
Carmichacl  Anstruther  of  Anstruther  and  Carmichael,  Baronet,  David  Erskino 
Esquire  of  Cardross,  James  Haig  Esquire  of  Bemcrside,  Charles  Riddell  Esquirc 
of  Dryburgh,  James  Erskine  Esquire  of  Shielfield,  James  Curle  Esquirc  of 
Ivclaw,  Adam  Fairholme  Esquire  of  (St  John's)  Chapcl,  George  Turnbull  Esquire 
of  Abbey  St  Bathans,  and  of  my  brother  Lieutenant-Colonel  George  Spottis- 
woode  of  Ciladswood,  to  all  of  whom  I  return  my  thanks  for  their  courtesy. 

Every  source  that  could  be  thought  of  to  complete  tlie  Rcgister  has  bccn 
explored,  and  the  result  of  the  search  will  be  found  in  the  Appendix,  which  con- 
tains  original  Charters,  Gifts,  Tacks  of  Teinds,  &c.,  and  several  old  Rentals  of 
the  Abbey,  whicli  are  curious,  and  may  bo  found  useful  in  assisting  to  show  the 
changes  produccd  by  time  on  the  value  both  of  land  and  of  money. 

JOHN  SPOTTISWOODE, 

Spottiswoode,  October  1847.

THE  EDITOR'S  PHEFACE. 


The  Register  of  tlie   Premonstratensian  Abbey  of  Dryburgh,  called  the 

"  LiBER   S.  Mari.13  de  Drtburgh,'"  from  which  the  prescnt  edition  has  Liber  dk 

been  printed,  is  a  sniall  folio  volume  of  paper,  containing  one  hundred 

and  twelve  leaves,  and  written  in  a  hand  of  the  sixteenth  century.     On 

a  blank  leaf  at  the  commcncement,  it  is  titled,  in  the  well-known  hand- 

writing  of  Sir  James  Balfour,  "  Liber  S.  Marice  de  Dri/brughe,  1635,"  and 

at  the  foot  of  the  first  remaining  page,  it   is  authenticatcd  with  the  sub- 

scription — "  Jacobus  Balfourius  KynardicB  Miles  Leo  Armorum  Rex." 

It  has  also  been  paged  by  him ;  and  it  is  probably  as  complete  now  as  when 

it  was  in  his  possession. 

It  is  to  be  regretted,  however,  that  the  Register  is  an  imperfect  col-  [mperfcction 
lection.  It  commences  with  charter  No.  6,  and  concludes  abruptly  in  the  ter. 
middle  of  a  charter,  No.  316.  Thc  first  fivc  charters  which  are  wanting 
may  havc  occupicd  two  leavcs  of  the  volume,  and  amongst  them,  probably, 
was  thc  foundation-charter  of  David  I.,  as  it  was  usual  to  commence  the 
registers  of  religious  houses  with  thcir  foundation  charters.  There  are  no 
means  of  ascertaining  how  many  charters  are  wanting  at  the  cnd.

Register,  it  is  also  to  be  regretted,  that  in  thc  greater  number  of  the  charters 
and  instruments  which  it  contains,  the  namcs  of  the  witnesscs  are  entirely 
omitted  ;  and  that  numerous  errors  occur  in  the  names  of  persons  and 
places.'

which  are  suspceted  have  been  sufFered  to  remain.  For  instance,  Eohertus  de  Morville 
appearing  as  a  benefactor  at  a  time  -svhen  Ekardus  was  the  known  person  of  tho  faraily, 
leads  to  a  doubt  that  the  Transcriber  may  have  mistaken  tlie  initial  letter  of  R.  in  the 
original  charter,  for  Robertus,  instead  of  Eicardus.  Again,  in  No.  243,  where  the  bishop  is 
reserving  dues  froni  the  church  of  Gullane,  the  words,  "  quatuor  marcis  nomine  procurationis 
nostre  et  quatuor  marcis  nomine  canonicorum,"  plainly  contain  some  mistake,  and  there  is 
reason  to  believe  that  the  scribe  has  written  canonicorum  for  cani  nostri :  The  Nuni-

Although  the  rules  of  the  Order  of  Prcemonstratenses,  thus  founded  at 
Dryburgh,  were  the  same  as  thoso  observed  in  other  slniilar  institutions,  and 
■which  are  well  known,  it  appears  approprlate  to  the  present  work,  and  may 
be  interesting,  as  this  is  the  first  of  the  Registers  of  that  rehgious  order 
whlch  has  been  published  in  Scotland,  to  give  a  short  account  of  their 
manners  and  employments. 

In  Brltain  they  vvere  usually  styled  Whitc  Canons,  from  the  colour  ofoRnEROp 
their  dress,  which  consisted  ot  a  white  cassock,  with  a  rochet  and  cape  over  it,  ti:nsf.3. 
a  long  white  cloak,  and  a  square  hat  or  bonnet,  of  whitc  felt.  They  likewlse 
wore  breeches  and  shocs,  but  no  shirt.  The  abbot  Avore  red  shoes,  and  a

Ordekoh       Church,  they  kept   a  fast  from   Holyrood   (September   14)  till  Easter  ;

In  time  of  hay-making  and  harvest,  they  went  to  work  early  in  the 
morning,  and  sometimes  did  not  return  home  till  after  Vespers ;  but  were 
bound  to  recite  their  prayers  in  the  fields  at  the  canonical  hours.  On  festivals 
they  did  no  work,  but  read  during  the  time  usually  appropriated  to  that 
purpose.  Instances,  however,  occur  of  special  dispensations  and  permis- 
sions  to  pcrform  work  on  such  occasions.  There  were  no  schools  in 
raonasteries  of  this  order  ;  but  no  onc  ignorant  of  Latin  could  be  admitted 
into  it.  The  lay  brethren  Avere  taught  to  recite  the  Creed,  tlie  Paternoster, 
Ave  Maria,  and  othcr  prayers  ;  but  were  not  allowed  books. '

of  the  Cistertian  priory  of  South  Berwick,  who,  he  declared,  had  indulged 
in  dissolute  and  incontinent  lives,  and  the  number  of  whom  had  been 
reduced  to  two.^

the  possessions  of  the  Nuns  of  South  Berwick  to  Dryburgh.^

kine."*'     Robert  the  elder  brother  was  killed  at  the  battle  of  Pinkie  in  1547,

On  the  other  hand,  it  has  been  stated  that  this  Abbot  was  John  Stewart, 
"  the  cousin  of  Lord  Darnley,  the  husband  of  Mary  Queen  of  Scots," — and

Abbot  John  Stewart,  not  cousin,  as  in  the  passage  just  quoted,  but  uncle 
to  Lord  Darnley ;  and  Mr  Morton  has  followed  this  latter  statemcnt.^ 

None  of  the  Charters  granted  by  this  Abbot,  which  have  been  recovered, 
contain  his  sirname,  and  no  authority  has  been  found  to  show  whcther  he 
was  of  the  Erskine  or  the  Stewart  family.  The  presumptions  are,  that  he 
was  of  the  former.  John  Erskine,  the  son  of  John  Loi-d  Erskine,  was 
Commendator  of  Inchmahomo  16th  August  1552,  and  he  was  succeeded  in 
that  ofRce,  in  1556,  by  his  nephew,  David  Erskine.^  This  David  Erskine, 
it  will  be  immediately  seen,  also  became  Commendator  of  Dryburgh  about 
the  same  time ;  and  the  probabiHty  is,  that  after  John  Erskine  succeeded  to 
the  title  of  Lord  Erskine,  on  the  death  of  his  father  in  1552,  and  betook 
himself  to  new  pursuits  and  «mployments,  he  had  resigned  the  offices  of 
Commendator  of  Dryburgh  and  Inchmahomo  in  favour  of  his  nephew, 
David  Erskine.  Another  nephew,  Adam  Erskine,  son  of  Thomas  Master 
of  Erskine,  was  made  Commendator  of  Cambuskenneth;  and  these  three 
religious  houses  continued  in  the  Erskine  faniily,  and  were  uUimately  crected 
into  the  Temporal  Lordship  of  Cardross,  in  favour  of  John  Earl  of  Mar,  as 
will  be  afterwards  stated.

On  lOth  June  1600,  a  Lease  of  teiuds  of  tlie  Mains  of  Mertoun  was  TheCommen- 
granted  by  David,  commendator  of  Dryburgli;  and  instead  of  its  bearing  contimled.

the  cniivent, 
deceSSlt.  '  '  sfac«rf m  1600. 

There  is  something  plaintive  in  this  declaration  of  the  death  of  all 
his  compeers  by  the  sole  surviving  representativc  of  this  rehgious  house, 
which  was  itself  destined,  in  a  short  time  thereafter,  to  undergo  a  further 
change. 

It  will  be  shown  that  in  1604  James  VI.  inchided  the  Abbacy  of  Dry- 
burgh  in  the  Temporal  Lordship  and  Barony  of  Cardross,  erected  in 
favour  of  John  Earl  of  Mar,  but  there  was  reserved  to  thc  Commendator 
the  Rents,  Profits,  and  Emoluments  of  the  Lands  and  others. 

In  virtue  of  this  reservation,  David  continued  to  grant  Leases  of  certain 
of  the  teinds  belonging  to  the  abbey.  One  of  the  Leases  bears  date 
30th  May  1608,  being  about  fifty  years  after  the  first  Lease  by  him  above 
mentioned,  which  shows  that  he  had  enjoyed  his  benefice  for  half  a  century. 
This  last  Lease  bears,  in  the  old  form,  to  be  with  consent  of  the  convent, 
although  they  had  all  "decessit"  at  least  eight  years  previously.  It  is 
subscribed  by  David  alone.^ 

The  granting  of  this  Lease  must  havc  been  among  the  last  ofHcial  acts  of 
David  Erskine,  commendator  of  Dryburgh ;  as  it  is  stated  in  a  Deed  of 
Provision  by  James  VL,  dated  on  31st  May  1608,  being  only  tho  day  after 
the  last-mentioned  Lease,  and  to  bc  immediately  noticed,  that  the  abbacy  Avas 
then  vacant,  and  in  his  Majesty's  hands  as  patron,  through  the  demission  of 
David  commendator  of  the  abbacy  of  Dryburgh.

Having  thus  traced  the  History  of  this  once  famous  Rehgious  House 

through  its  various  vicissitudes,  from  its  Foundation  to  the  present  time, 

we  shall  close  these  Prefatory  Remarks  wlth  a  parting  glance  at  the  situa- 

tion  and  ruins  of  the  Abbey. 

situationof        Dryburgh  is  situated  in  the  parish  of  Mertoun,  on  the  south-western 

the  Abbey,  its  J  a  r 

rmm.appear-  ponfines  of  thc  countv  of  Bcrwick.     It  stands  three  miles  below  Melrose, 

ance,  ^t.  •'  ' 

and  ten  miles  above  Kelso,  on  a  fiat  sequestered  lawn,  on  the  north  side  of 
the  Tweed,  nearly  surrounded  by  one  of  its  finest  tui-ns,  with  high  woody 
banks  on  every  side,  and  in  sight  of  the  celebrated  and  picturesque  Eildon 
Hills,  the  Trimontium  of  the  Romans.  Such  a  situation  seems  to  have 
been  pecuUarly  suited  for  retirement  from  the  world  and  the  enjoyment  of 
the  recluse  monastic  Hfe. 

The  abbey  and  its  church  have  been  so  often  ruined  and  repaired,  altered 
and  added  to,  that  it  becomes  difficult  to  trace  the  plan  of  the  building,  or 
to  ascertain  the  age  of  its  different  parts.  There  is  nothing,  however,  in 
Dr)'burgh  which  the  student  of  early  architecture  can  place  before  the 
twelfth  century,  and  but  Httle  of  that  period  is  preserved.  The  now  roofless 
ruins,  covered  here  and  there  with  ivy,  and  intermingled  with  lofty  trees, 
contrasting  with  the  beauty  of  the  surrounding  scenerj^,  render  the  whole 
remarkably  imposing  and  picturesque. 

^  Title-deeds  of  Dnburgh  in  the  possessiou  of  the  Earl  of  Buclian. 


THE    PREFACE.  xxxvii 

Dryburgb,  since  it  became  the  grave  of  Scott,  has  been  invested  with  an 
additional  interest.  It  was  preferred  by  him,  that  his  own  remains  mioht 
mingle  with  those  of  his  maternal  ancestors,  the  HaHburtons.  But  it  was, 
in  any  view,  a  fitting  place  of  sepulture  for  the  Great  Minstrel  of  the  Scot- 
tish  Border.  There,  amidst  the  dust  of  the  powerful  De  Morvilles,  and 
many  a  holy  Abbot  and  Monk  of  old,  and  surrounded  by  the  ashes  6i  his 
own  "rough  clan,"  under  walls  scorched  in  many  a  Border  foray,  in  the 
heart  of  the  valley  he  lovcd  so  well,  and  of  the  scenes  he  sung,  he  the 
mortal  remains  of  that  miglity  Master  who  has  thrown  a  charm  over  the 
country,  its  history,  and  its  traditions,  that  will  hve  as  long  as  theinselves. 

Edinbukgh,  October  1847.
